question: At low temperatures, a mixture of ${ }^{3} \text{He}$ and ${ }^{4} \text{He}$ atoms form a liquid which separates into two phases: a concentrated phase (nearly pure ${ }^{3} \text{He}$), and a dilute phase (roughly $6.5 \text{\textperthousand} { }^{3} \text{He}$ for $T \text{\textless}= 0.1 \text{ K}$). The lighter ${ }^{3} \text{He}$ floats on top of the dilute phase, and ${ }^{3} \text{He}$ atoms can cross the phase boundary (see Fig. 2.23). The superfluid ${ }^{4} \text{He}$ has negligible excitation, and the thermodynamics of the dilute phase can be represented as an ideal degenerate Fermi gas of particles with density $n_{d}$ and effective mass $m^{*}\text{(}m^{*}\text{ is larger than }m_{3}\text{, the mass of the bare }{ }^{3} \text{He atom, due to the presence of the liquid }{ }^{4} \text{He, actually }m^{*}=2.4 m_{3}\text{)}$. We can crudely represent the concentrated phase by an ideal degenerate Fermi gas of density $n_{c}$ and particle mass $m_{3}$. How much heat is required to warm each phase from $T=0 \text{ K}$ to $T$?
subject: TSM
caption:
IMAGE 1:
Rectangular container with two horizontal layers: the upper layer is labeled as "concentrated phase of $^3$He;" the lower, dotted layer is labeled as "dilute phase of $^3$He (in superfluid of $^4$He);" layers are separated flatly, showing spatial phase separation of helium-3 in a superfluid helium-4 background.

question: The figure below shows an apparatus for the determination of $C_{p} / C_{v}$ for a gas, according to the method of Clement and Desormes. A bottle $G$, of reasonable capacity (say a few litres), is fitted with a tap $H$, and a manometer $M$. The difference in pressure between the inside and the outside can thus be determined by observation of the difference $h$ in heights of the two columns in the manometer. The bottle is filled with the gas to be investigated, at a very slight excess pressure over the outside atmospheric pressure. The bottle is left in peace (with the tap closed) until the temperature of the gas in the bottle is the same as the outside temperature in the room. Let the reading of the manometer be $h_{i}$. The tap $H$ is then opened for a very short time, just sufficient for the internal pressure to become equal to the atmospheric pressure (in which case the manometer reads $h=0$ ). With the tap closed the bottle is left in peace for a while, until the inside temperature has become equal to the outside temperature. Let the final reading of the manometer be $h$. From the values of $h_{i}$ and $h_{f}$ it is possible to find $C_{p} / C_{v}$. Suppose that the gas in question is oxygen. What is your theoretical prediction for $C_{p} / C_{v}$ at $20^{\text{C}}$, within the framework of statistical mechanics?
subject: TSM
caption:
IMAGE 1:
A vessel $G$ is sealed with a stopper $H$ connected to a manometer $M$ via tubing; the manometer contains a fluid column of height $h$, indicating a pressure difference relative to atmospheric pressure.

question: A beam of neutrons (mass $m$ ) traveling with nonrelativistic speed $v$ impinges on the system shown in Fig. 1.7, with beam-splitting mirrors at corners $B$ and $D$, mirrors at $A$ and $C$, and a neutron detector at $E$. The corners all make right angles, and neither the mirrors nor the beam-splitters affect the neutron spin. The beams separated at $B$ rejoin coherently at $D$, and the detector $E$ reports the neutron intensity $I$. In this part of the problem, assume the system to be in a vertical plane (so gravity points down parallel to AB and DC ). Given that detector intensity was $I_{0}$ with the system in a horizontal plane, derive an expression for the intensity $I_{g}$ for the vertical configuration.

IMAGE 1:
Diagram of a neutron beam apparatus: incident neutrons enter at point B and travel horizontally through a labeled "region of magnetic field," then follow two possible paths: B→A→D→E (top path) and B→C→D→E (bottom path). Distances are labeled $L$ (horizontal from A to D and from C to D) and $s$ (vertical from B to A and from C to D). Vector $\vec{H}$ points vertically downward, vectors $s$ point vertically upward, and vector $\vec{l}$ at D makes an angle $\theta$ with the vertical. The final neutron detector is labeled E. Arrows indicate the direction of neutron motion along each segment.

question: A long solenoid of radius $b$ and length $l$ is wound so that the axial magnetic field is $$\mathbf{B}=\begin{cases} B_{0}\,\mathbf{e}_{z}, & r<b,\\ 0, & r>b, \end{cases}$$ A particle of charge $q$ is emitted with velocity $v$ perpendicular to a central rod of radius $a$ (see Fig. 2.59). The electric force on the particle is given by $qE=f(r)\,\mathbf{e}_{r}$, where $\mathbf{e}_{r}\cdot\mathbf{e}_{z}=0$. We assume $\mathbf{v}$ is sufficiently large so that the particle passes out of the solenoid and does so without hitting the solenoid. If the electric field inside the solenoid is zero before the particle leaves the rod and after the particle has gone far away, it becomes $$\mathbf{E}=\begin{cases} -\frac{q}{2\pi\varepsilon_{0}lr}\,\mathbf{e}_{r}, & r>a,\\ 0, & r<a, \end{cases}$$ calculate the electromagnetic field angular momentum and discuss the final state of the solenoid if the solenoid can rotate freely about its axis. Neglect end effects.
subject: EM

The direction of the current $I$ is indicated as outward, and all relevant distances $a$, $b$, and $r$ are labeled.

question:
According to the Weinberg-Salam model, the Higgs boson $\phi$ couples to every elementary fermion $f$ ( $f$ may be a quark or lepton) in the form
$$
\frac{e m_{f}}{m_{W}} \phi \bar{f} f,
$$
where $m_{f}$ is the mass of the fermion $f, e$ is the charge of the electron, and $m_{W}$ is the mass of the $W$ boson. Some theorists believe that the Higgs boson weighs approximately 10 GeV . question:
The study of the scattering of high energy electrons from nuclei has yielded much interesting information about the charge distributions in nuclei and nucleons. We shall here consider a simple version in which the electrons are supposed to have zero spin. We also assume that the nucleus, of charge $Z e$, remains fixed in space (i.e., its mass is assumed infinite). Let $\rho(\mathbf{x})$ denote the charge density in the nucleus. The charge distribution is assumed to be spherically symmetric but otherwise arbitrary.

Let $f_{c}\left(\mathbf{p}_{i}, \mathbf{p}_{f}\right)$, where $\mathbf{p}_{i}$ is the initial and $\mathbf{p}_{f}$ the final momentum, be the scattering amplitude in the first Born approximation for the scattering of an electron from a point-nucleus of charge $Z e$. Let $f\left(\mathbf{p}_{i}, \mathbf{p}_{f}\right)$ be the scattering amplitude of an electron from a real nucleus of the same charge. Let $\mathbf{q}=\mathbf{p}_{i}-\mathbf{p}_{f}$ denote the momentum transfer. The quantity $F$ defined by
$$ f\left(\mathbf{p}_{i}, \mathbf{p}_{f}\right)=F\left(q^{2}\right) f_{c}\left(\mathbf{p}_{i}, \mathbf{p}_{f}\right) $$
is called the form factor. It is easily seen that F , in fact, depends on $\mathbf{p}_{i}$ and $\mathbf{p}_{f}$ only through the quantity $q^{2}$.
 Figure 2.3 shows some experimental results pertaining to the form factor for the proton, and we shall regard our theory as applicable to these data. On the basis of the data shown, compute the root-mean-square (charge) radius of the proton. Hint: Note that there is a simple relationship between the root-mean-square radius and the derivative of $F\left(q^{2}\right)$ with respect to $q^{2}$, at $q^{2}=0$. Find this relationship, and then compute.
subject: QMIT
caption:
IMAGE 1:
Scatter plot showing the form factor $F(q^2)$ (vertical axis) versus $(q/\hbar)^2$ in units of $10^{26}\ \mathrm{cm}^{-2}$ (horizontal axis), with data points indicated by circles and associated error bars; both axes are clearly labeled, and the plot is titled as Fig. 2.3.

Metallic diffraction grating.
Purcell (Phys. Rev. 92, 1069) has shown that electromagnetic radiation is emitted from a metallic diffraction grating when a beam of charged particles passes near and parallel to the surface of the grating.

The velocity of the charged particles is $v$ and the grating spacing is $d$. Consider only the light emitted in the plane perpendicular to the grating and containing the particle trajectory. Suppose the metallic grating is replaced by a transmission grating, e.g., a piece of glass with grooves ruled onto it, still $d$ apart. In what way, if any, will this change the emitted radiation?
Explain qualitatively.

(b) Diagram depicts a set of parallel lines in the $xz$-plane suggesting planes or slits, with trajectory lines originating from $O$ making an angle $\theta$ with the $x$-axis in the $xz$-plane; axes $x$, $y$, and $z$ are labeled from $O$.

question:

\[
H_{	ext{c}}(T)=H_{0}\left[1-\left( rac{T}{T_{	ext{c}}}ight)^{2}ight]\]
the normal state undergoes a phase transition to a new state, the $S$ phase. In the $S$ state, it is found that $B=0$ inside the material. The phase diagram is shown below. At $H=0$, compute the discontinuity in the specific heat as the material transforms from the $N$ to the $S$ phase.

question: It is believed that nucleons $(\mathrm{N})$ interact directly through the weak interaction and that the latter violates parity conservation. One way to study the nature of the $\mathrm{N}-\mathrm{N}$ weak interaction is by means of $\alpha$-decay, as typified by the decays of the $3^{+}, T=1$ and $3^{-}, T=0$ states of ${ }^{20} \mathrm{Ne}$ (Fig. 2.29). In the following you will be asked to explain the principles of an experiment to measure the weak-interaction matrix element between these states, $\left\langle 3^{+}\right| H_{\text {weak }}\left|3^{-}\right\rangle$. Allowing for a parity-violating matrix element $\left\langle 3^{+}\right| H_{\text {weak }}\left|3^{-}\right\rangle$of 1 eV , estimate the $\alpha$ width of the parity-forbidden transition, $\Gamma_{\alpha}$ (forbidden), in terms of the $\alpha$ width of the parity-allowed transition, $\Gamma_{\alpha}$ (allowed). Assume $\Gamma_{\alpha}$ (allowed) is small compared with the separation energy between the $3^{+}, 3^{-}$states.
subject: AMONP
caption:

Energy level diagram illustrating the excitation of $^{20}\mathrm{Ne}$ nuclei, with energy levels labeled by spin-parity (e.g., $0^+$, $2^+$, $3^*$) and energy (in MeV) along the right side; $^{16}\mathrm{O} + \alpha$ (alpha particle) entrance channel shown at 4.730 MeV with two diagonal arrows connecting to excited states of $^{20}\mathrm{Ne}$; possible transitions to excited states (marked as "many levels") and to higher-lying states ($3^*$, $T=0$ at 10.838 MeV and $3^*$, $T=1$ at 10.890 MeV); horizontal lines on the right indicate energy thresholds for $^{19}\mathrm{F} + d \rightarrow n$ at 10.620 MeV and $^{19}\mathrm{F} + {}^{3}\mathrm{He} \rightarrow d$ at 7.350 MeV. Energy level separations and object labels are explicitly marked.

question: A semi-infinite electrical network is formed from condensers $C$ and inductances $L$, as shown in Fig. 3.84. question: The Stark effect. The energy levels of the $n=2$ states of atomic hydrogen are illustrated in Fig. 5.14. The $S_{1/2}$ and $P_{1/2}$ levels are degenerate at an energy $\varepsilon_{0}$ and the $P_{3/2}$ level is degenerate at an energy $\varepsilon_{0}+A$. A uniform static electric field $E$ applied to the atom shifts the states to energies $\varepsilon_{1}$, $\varepsilon_{2}$ and $\varepsilon_{3}$. Assuming that all states other than these three are far enough away to be neglected, diagonalize the Hamiltonian in the $P_{1/2}$ and $S_{1/2}$ subspace and determine the energies of the resulting states to second order in the electric field $E$, using the provided perturbation Hamiltonian.
subject: AMONP

Energy level diagram showing levels labeled $S_{1/2}$ at energy $\epsilon_0$, $P_{1/2}$ at a higher energy, and $P_{3/2}$ at energy $\epsilon_0 \cdot \Delta$; all levels are represented by horizontal lines, with the vertical axis indicating energy.

question: A point source $Q$ emits coherent light isotropically at two frequencies $w$ and $w+ \Delta w$ with equal power I joules/sec at each frequency. Two detectors $A$ and $B$ each with a (small) sensitive area $s$, capable of responding to individual photons are located at distances $l_{A}$ and $l_{B}$ from $Q$ as shown in Fig. 8.4. In the following take $\Delta \omega/\omega\ll1$ and assume the experiment is carried out in vacuum. If now the output pulses from $A$ and $B$ are put into a coincidence circuit of resolving time $\tau$, what is the time-averaged coincidence counting rate? Assume that $\tau\ll 1/\Delta \omega$ and recall that a coincidence circuit will produce an output pulse if the two input pulses arrive within a time $\tau$ of each other.
subject: OPT

Both $A$ and $B$ are associated with rectangular blocks oriented perpendicular to the dashed lines, indicating that $A$ and $B$ lie on lines or surfaces perpendicular to $QA$ and $QB$ at those points.

question: A cylinder contains a perfect gas in thermodynamic equilibrium at $p, V, T, U$ (internal energy) and $S$ (entropy). The cylinder is surrounded by a very large heat reservoir at the same temperature $T$. The cylinder walls and piston can be either perfect thermal conductors or perfect thermal insulators. The piston is moved to produce a small volume change $\nabla V$. "Slow" or "fast" means that during the volume change the speed of the piston is very much less than, or very much greater than, molecular speeds at temperature $T$. For each of the five processes below show (on your answer sheet) whether the changes (after the reestablishment of equilibrium) in the other quantities have been positive, negative, or zero.
subject: TSM
caption:
IMAGE 1:
A thermodynamic piston-cylinder setup, with a movable piston sealing a gas characterized by pressure $p$, volume $V$, and temperature $T$; additional variables $U$ (internal energy) and $S$ (entropy) are indicated inside the gas. The walls (except for the piston face) appear labeled as $T$. The piston is shown moving right for $+\Delta V$ and left for $-\Delta V$ (arrows labeled accordingly). No forces or heat flows are depicted; only direction of volume change is shown. A table for changes in $\Delta T$, $\Delta U$, $\Delta S$, and $\Delta p$ is provided, alongside a keyed list of processes specifying $+\Delta V$ or $-\Delta V$, "slow" or "fast," and "conduct" or "insulate" (referencing heat conduction or insulation).

question: A beam of neutrons (mass $m$ ) traveling with nonrelativistic speed $v$ impinges on the system shown in Fig. 1.7, with beam-splitting mirrors at corners $B$ and $D$, mirrors at $A$ and $C$, and a neutron detector at $E$. The corners all make right angles, and neither the mirrors nor the beam-splitters affect the neutron spin. The beams separated at $B$ rejoin coherently at $D$, and the detector $E$ reports the neutron intensity $I$. For this part of the problem, suppose the system lies in a horizontal plane. A uniform magnetic field, pointing out of the plane, acts in the dotted region indicated which encompasses a portion of the leg BC. The incident neutrons are polarized with spin pointing along BA as shown. The neutrons which pass through the magnetic field region will have their spins pressed by an amount depending on the field strength. Suppose the spin expectation value presses through an angle $\theta$ as shown. Let $I(\theta)$ be the intensity at the detector $E$. Derive $I(\theta)$ as a function of $\theta$, given that $I(\theta=0)=I_{0}$.
subject: AMONP
caption:
IMAGE 1:
Diagram shows a rectangular neutron interferometer with labeled points $A$, $B$, $C$, and $D$ connected by narrow pathways: incident neutrons enter at $B$, split at $A$ and $B$, traverse paths of length $L$ horizontally and length $s$ vertically, passing through a “Region of magnetic field” on lower path, recombine at $D$, and exit to detector $E$. Vectors shown: incident neutron direction (left to right along $B$ to $C$), path segment $H$ indicating vertical separation (downward arrow), spin vector $s$ (upwards at $A$ and $C$), and a vector at angle $\theta$ to vertical near $C$. All mirror and beam splitter surfaces are indicated by diagonal lines; the upper horizontal path is $AD$, and the lower is $BC$.

question: It is believed that nucleons $(\mathrm{N})$ interact directly through the weak interaction and that the latter violates parity conservation. One way to study the nature of the $\mathrm{N}-\mathrm{N}$ weak interaction is by means of $\alpha$-decay, as typified by the decays of the $3^{+}, T=1$ and $3^{-}, T=0$ states of ${ }^{20} \mathrm{Ne}$ (Fig. 2.29). In the following you will be asked to explain the principles of an experiment to measure the weak-interaction matrix element between these states, $\left\langle 3^{+}\right| H_{\text {weak }}\left|3^{-}\right\rangle$. There is also a $1^{+} / 1^{-}$parity doublet at $\sim 11.23 \mathrm{MeV}$. Both states have $T=1$. As in part(a), which isospin components of the weak N-N interaction contribute to the mixing matrix element? (Note that ${ }^{20} \mathrm{Ne}$ is self-conjugate) Which would be determined by a measurement of the parity-forbidden $\alpha$ width?
subject: AMONP

question: Point charge in the field of a magnetic monopole. The equation of motion of a point electric charge $e$, of mass $m$, in the field of a magnetic monopole of strength $g$ at the origin is $m \ddot{\mathbf{r}} = -g e \frac{\dot{\mathbf{r}} \times \mathbf{r}}{r^{3}}$. The monopole may be taken as infinitely heavy. Define a new variable \(\mathbf{R}\) by \(\mathbf{R} = \frac{1}{\sin \xi} \hat{\mathbf{J}} \times (\mathbf{r} \times \hat{\mathbf{J}}) = \frac{1}{\sin \xi} [\mathbf{r} - \hat{\mathbf{J}} (\mathbf{r} \cdot \hat{\mathbf{J}})]\), where \(\hat{\mathbf{J}} = \frac{\mathbf{J}}{|\mathbf{J}|}\) and \(R = |\mathbf{r}| = |\mathbf{R}|\). You may use the fact that \(m \mathbf{R} \times \dot{\mathbf{R}} = \mathbf{J}\). Find the equation of motion for \(\mathbf{R}\).

question: A spaceship is in a circular orbit of radius $r_{0}$ around a star of mass $M$. question: Consider a one-dimensional chain consisting of $n \\gg 1$ segments as illustrated in the figure. Let the length of each segment be $a$ when the long dimension of the segment is parallel to the chain and zero when the segment is vertical (i.e., long dimension normal to the chain direction). Each segment has just two states, a horizontal orientation and a vertical orientation, and each of these states is not degenerate. The distance between the chain ends is $n x$. Under which conditions does your answer lead to Hook's law?
subject: TSM
caption:
IMAGE 1:
Diagram showing a longitudinal wave propagating to the right along the $x$-axis, with alternating compressed and rarefied regions, and labeled coordinate direction $nx$ marked by a bold arrow.

question: $D(E)$ is the density of states in a metal, and $E_{\text{F}}$ is the Fermi energy. At the Fermi energy $D\big(E_{\text{F}}\big) \neq 0$. Calculate the temperature dependence of the chemical potential at low temperatures, i.e., $\text{μ} \text{≫} k T$. (Remember: $\text{∫}_{-\text{∞}}^{+\text{∞}} \frac{x e^{x}}{\big(e^{x}+1\big)^{2}} d x=\frac{\text{π}^{2}}{3}$.)
subject: TSM
caption:

A plot of the density of states $D(E)$ (vertical axis) versus energy $E$ (horizontal axis), with a distinct vertical marker at the Fermi energy $E_F$; both axes are indicated with arrows showing positive directions.

question: At low temperatures, a mixture of ${ }^{3} \text{He}$ and ${ }^{4} \text{He}$ atoms form a liquid which separates into two phases: a concentrated phase (nearly pure ${ }^{3} \text{He}$), and a dilute phase (roughly $6.5 \text{\textperthousand} { }^{3} \text{He}$ for $T \text{\textless}= 0.1 \text{ K}$). The lighter ${ }^{3} \text{He}$ floats on top of the dilute phase, and ${ }^{3} \text{He}$ atoms can cross the phase boundary (see Fig. 2.23). The superfluid ${ }^{4} \text{He}$ has negligible excitation, and the thermodynamics of the dilute phase can be represented as an ideal degenerate Fermi gas of particles with density $n_{d}$ and effective mass $m^{*}\text{(}m^{*}\text{ is larger than }m_{3}\text{, the mass of the bare }{ }^{3} \text{He atom, due to the presence of the liquid }{ }^{4} \text{He, actually }m^{*}=2.4 m_{3}\text{)}$. We can crudely represent the concentrated phase by an ideal degenerate Fermi gas of density $n_{c}$ and particle mass $m_{3}$. Calculate the Fermi energies for the two fluids.
subject: TSM
caption:
IMAGE 1:
A rectangular container is horizontally divided into two regions: the upper layer contains the concentrated phase of $^3$He, and the lower layer consists of the dilute phase of $^3$He mixed in superfluid $^4$He, as labeled. No forces or vectors are shown in the diagram.

question: At low temperatures, a mixture of ${ }^{3} \text{He}$ and ${ }^{4} \text{He}$ atoms form a liquid which separates into two phases: a concentrated phase (nearly pure ${ }^{3} \text{He}$), and a dilute phase (roughly $6.5 \text{\textperthousand} { }^{3} \text{He}$ for $T \text{\textless}= 0.1 \text{ K}$). Find: the most probable speed of molecules in the beam;

question: The schematic drawing below (Fig. 2.42) shows the experimental set up for the production of a well-collimated beam of sodium atoms for an atomic beam experiment. Sodium is present in the oven $S$, which is kept at the temperature $T=550 \text{ K}$. At this temperature the vapor pressure of sodium is $p=6 \times 10^{-3}$ torr. The sodium atoms emerge through a slit in the wall of the oven. The hole is rectangular, with dimensions 10 mm $\times 0.1 \text{ mm}$. The collimator $C$ has a hole of identical size and shape, and the sodium atoms which pass through $C$ thus constitute the atomic beam under consideration. The atomic mass of sodium is 23. The distance $d$ in the figure is 10 cm. The region in which the beam propagates must, of course, be a reasonably good vacuum. Estimate (and give answer in torr) just how good the vacuum ought to be if the beam is to remain collimated for at least 1 meter. (1 torr $=1 \text{ mmHg}$).
subject: TSM
caption:
IMAGE 1:
A sodium source labeled "Na" is enclosed in box $S$, emitting a beam shown as a dashed line directed horizontally to the right toward point $C$; distance between $S$ and $C$ is marked as $d$. The beam passes through $C$ and continues rightward, indicated by an arrow labeled "to experiment."

question:
Consider a one-dimensional solid of length \(L=N a\) made up of \(N\) diatomic molecules, the interatomic spacing within a molecule is \(b\left(b< rac{a}{2}ight)\). The centers of adjacent molecules are a distance \(a\) apart. We represent the potential energy as a sum of delta functions centered on each atom:
\[
V=-A \sum_{n=0}^{N-1}\left[\delta\left(x-n a+ rac{b}{2}ight)+\delta\left(x-n a- rac{b}{2}ight)ight]
\]
with \(A\) a positive quantity and \(n=0,1,2, \ldots, N-1\). The potential is shown in Fig. 1.18. Expressing the potential as a Fourier series
\[
V=\sum_{q} V_{q} e^{i q x}
\]
find the allowed values of \(q\) and the coefficients \(V_{q}\).
subject: AMONP
caption:

Diagram shows a one-dimensional periodic potential well array along the $x$-axis, with potential wells of width $b$ spaced at intervals $a$; positions are labeled at $x=0$, $x=a$, and $x=(N-1)a$ for a total of $N$ wells.

question: Consider a one-dimensional periodic potential $U(x)$ viewed as an array of identical potential barriers $V(x)$ of width $a$, centered at the points $x= \\pm n a$ where $n$ is an integer. The barrier $V(x)$, schematically drawn in Fig. 1.19, may be characterized by a transmission coefficient $t(k)$ and a reflection coefficient $r(k)$ for an electron incident on the barrier with energy $E=\\frac{\\hbar^{2} \\kappa^{2}}{2 m}$. Suppose the barriers are weak, i.e., $|t|=1$ and $|r|=0$, find a simple expression for the width of the energy gaps.
subject: QMIT

question:
Recently, a "double" quasar was discovered consisting of two indistinguishable images separated by an angle of 6 arc seconds. One interpretation is that we are seeing one quasar imaged as two by an intervening gravitational lens. To analyse this, suppose that the observer, the intervening galaxy, and the quasar are exactly lined up as indicated in Fig. 2.6.

Light from the quasar is gravitationally bent by the galaxy before reaching us. The angle $\phi$, as measured in the rest frame of the galaxy, is given by $\phi=4 M / r$, where $M$ is the mass of the galaxy and $r$ the impact parameter of the light ray. Thus, as seen by us, the quasar is a ring whose diameter subtends an angle $2 	heta$. The universe has a geometry described by the metric
\[
d s^{2}=-d t^{2}+a^{2}(t)\left(d ho^{2}+ho^{2} d 	heta^{2}+ho^{2} \sin ^{2} 	heta d \phi^{2}ight)
\]
The scale factor is $a(t) \propto t^{2 / 3}$. The quasar emits radiation at $t=t_{2}$, which passes the galaxy at time $t_{1}$ and reaches us at $t_{0}$. Find an expression which relates $	heta$ to $M, t_{0}, t_{1}$ and $t_{2}$.
subject: ACG

Triangle geometry showing points $O$, $Q_1$, and $Q_2$, with vectors $r$, $\vec{\rho}_1$, and $\vec{\rho}_2$ connecting these points; angle $\theta$ at $O$, angle $\phi$ at the base between $r$ and the dashed horizontal line; $r$ is the distance between $Q_1$ and the dashed line, and all vectors and angles are labeled accordingly.

question:

question: A photomultiplier tube is to be used to detect light pulses each of which consists of a small but fixed number of photons. The average photoelectric efficiency is $10 \%$. That is, a photon has a $10 \%$ probability of causing the emission of a detectable photoelectron. Assume the photomultiplier gain is $10^{6}$ and that the output current as a function of time can be approximated as shown in Fig. 3.6. What is $N$, the average number of photons in each pulse?
subject: AMONP

question: Suppose a search for solar neutrinos is to be mounted using a large sample of lithium enriched in the isotope $ {}_{3}^{7} \text{Li}$. question: Inelastic neutrino scattering in the quark model. Consider the scattering of neutrinos on free, massless quarks. question:
According to the Weinberg-Salam model, the Higgs boson $\phi$ couples to every elementary fermion $f$ ( $f$ may be a quark or lepton) in the form
$$
\frac{e m_{f}}{m_{W}} \phi \bar{f} f,
$$
where $m_{f}$ is the mass of the fermion $f, e$ is the charge of the electron, and $m_{W}$ is the mass of the $W$ boson. Assuming that the Higgs boson decays primarily to the known quarks and leptons, calculate its lifetime in terms
of its mass $m_{H}$. You may assume that the Higgs boson is much heavier than the known quarks and leptons.

question:
High energy neutrino beams at Fermilab are made by first forming a monoenergetic $
\pi^{+}$(or $K^{+}$) beam and then allowing the pions to decay by 
$$
\pi^{+} \rightarrow \mu^{+}+
u
$$

Recall that the mass of the pion is $140 \mathrm{MeV} / c^{2}$ and the mass of the muon is $106 \mathrm{MeV} / c^{2}$. In the laboratory frame, the energy of the decay neutrino depends on the decay angle $\theta$ (see Fig. 4.6). Suppose the $\pi^{+}$beam has an energy $200 \mathrm{GeV} / c^{2}$. Find the angle $\theta$ at which the neutrino's energy has fallen to half of its maximum energy.
subject: AMONP

question: Consider a $2-\text{cm}$ thick plastic scintillator directly coupled to the surface of a photomultiplier with a gain of $10^{6}$. question:
The "charmed" particles observed in $e^{+} e^{-}$storage rings have not yet been seen in hadron-hadron interactions. One possible means for detecting such particles is the observation of muons resulting from their leptonic decays. For example, consider a charmed particle $c$ with decay mode 
$$ c \rightarrow \mu 
u $$ Unfortunately, the experimental situation is complicated by the presence of muons from $\pi$ decays. Consider an experiment at Fermilab in which 400 GeV protons strike a thick iron target (beam dump) as depicted in Fig. 4.13. Some of the muons entering the detector will be from $\pi$ decays and some from $c$ decays (ignore other processes). Calculate the ratio of muons from $c$ decays to those from $\pi$ decays under the following assumptions: the pions that have suffered interaction in the dump completely disappear from the beam, the energy spectra of both $\pi$ and $c$ are flat from minimum up to the maximum possible energy, the mass of the $c$ is $2 \mathrm{GeV} / c^{2}$ and its lifetime is $\ll 10^{-10} \mathrm{sec}$, one can ignore muon energy loss in the iron, one can ignore any complications due to the geometry of the muon detector, the $p-p$ inelastic cross section is 30 mb , and the mean charged pion multiplicity in inelastic interactions is 8 . Be specific. State any additional assumptions. Give a numerical value for the ratio at $E_{\mu}=100 \mathrm{GeV}$ assuming the total production cross section for $c$ to be $10 \mu b$ per Fe nucleus and that it decays to $\mu 
u 10 \%$ of the time.
subject: AMONP
caption:
IMAGE 1:
A horizontal $p$ beam is directed toward a rectangular block labeled "Iron (beam dump)." To the right of the iron block, a square labeled "$\mu$ detector" is positioned, indicating a setup where the proton beam hits the iron dump and the muon detector is placed downstream to detect particles produced from the interaction. The arrow shows the direction of the $p$ beam toward the iron block.

question:

\[
E_{2}=A \cos \left(\omega t- rac{2 \pi x}{\lambda}ight) .
\]

question:
如果存在磁荷（磁单极子），那么在对磁荷量 $q_{\mathrm{m}}$ 的单位作适当定义后，真空中麦克斯韦方程组的微分形式应补充修改为下述形式：
$$
\left\{
\begin{array}{l}
\nabla \cdot \boldsymbol{E} = \frac{\rho}{\varepsilon_{0}} \\
\nabla \cdot \boldsymbol{B} = \frac{\rho_{\mathrm{m}}}{\mu_{0}} \\
\nabla \times \boldsymbol{E} = -\frac{\partial \boldsymbol{B}}{\partial t} - \frac{1}{\mu_{0}} \boldsymbol{j}_{\mathrm{m}} \\
\nabla \times \boldsymbol{B} = \mu_{0} \varepsilon_{0} \frac{\partial \boldsymbol{E}}{\partial t} + \mu_{0} \boldsymbol{j}
\end{array}
\right.
$$

式中：$\rho$ 和 $\boldsymbol{j}$ 分别为电荷密度和电流密度；$\rho_{\mathrm{m}}$ 和 $\boldsymbol{j}_{\mathrm{m}}$ 分别为磁荷密度和磁流密度。

为了寻找磁荷，物理学家设计了如电图 5.19.1 所示的实验。图中，由 $n$ 匝线圈和电量计或电流表 G 构成回路。让可能带有磁荷 $q_{\mathrm{m}}$ 的物质碎块连续 $N$ 次通过线圈，若 $q_{\mathrm{m}} \neq 0$，则在线圈中会形成可以测出的电流。

设线圈总电阻为 $R$，而自感 $L$ 可略。试问：磁荷 $q_{\mathrm{m}}$ 经线圈环行 $N$ 周后有多少电荷 $Q$ 通过线圈？
subject: EM
caption:

question: In a Michelson interferometer with point light source S, having central wavelength \lambda_{0} and width of the spectral contour \Delta \lambda, one of the mirrors ( \mathrm{M}_{2} in the figure) harmonically oscillates with amplitude l_{0} \gg l_{c}, where l_{c} is the length of temporal coherence. question: 如图所示，质量为 $M$ ，宽度为 $d$ 的木块静放在光滑水平地面上，与一端固定在墙上，劲度系数为 $k$ 且处于自由长度状态的轻弹簧相连。一质量可略，质量为 $m$ 的子弹以 $v_{0}$ 速度水平射向木块，在穿透木块的过程中，受到木块的摩擦阻力恒为常量 $F$ 。木块第一次朝右运动过程中其速度会有一个极大值，不同的初速度 $v_{0}$ 对应的此极大值不尽相同，试找出这些极大值中的最大者 $v_{\text{max}}$ ，已知在子弹穿透木块过程中，木块的质量不因子弹的打击而变化且有 $k d \geqslant 2 F$ ， $m / M \geqslant 5 / 4$.

Determine an expression for the magnitude $p$ of the momentum of the electron as it enters the magnetic field.
subject: CM

All vectors indicate the direction of the electron's velocity.

question: 如热图 3．26．1 所示，半径为 $r$ 的圆柱形保险丝与电路中的两个电阻块 A 和 B连接。设 A 和 B 与周围环境具有相同的恒定温度 $T_{\text{c}}$ 。设保险丝中通过稳恒电流 $I$ ，保险丝已达到热稳定状态，设保险丝中任一正截面上的温度都相同，记为 $T_{\text{c}}+T$ ，不同正截面上的温度不同，若某正截面与 A 相距为 $x$ ，它的温度表示为 $T(x)$ 。设保险丝的电阻率为 $\rho$ ，设保险丝沿其长度方向 （即 $x$ 方向）的热传导率为 $\lambda$ ，设保险丝单位时间通过其侧面单位面积向外界散发的热量为 $C T$ ，其中 $C$ 为常量，试求保险丝上的温度分布，即求 $T(x)$ 函数，试就 $l$ $\gg\left(\frac{\lambda r}{2 C}\right)^{\frac{1}{2}}$ 的所谓长保险丝情形，计算能使长保险丝熔断的电流强度，设保险丝材料的熔点为 $T_{\text{m}}$ 。

question:
如热图 3.2.1 所示，一块平而薄的长方形钨质玻璃板，用两根质量可略的等长细线悬挂起来，玻璃板两个表面的半个面分别对称地涂了一层化学性质活泼的金属，整个装置放在容器之中，容器内有压强为 p 的氢气。

设每一个氢气分子遇到金属分子后发生化学反应的概率为 q(q<1) ，且 q 为恒量，设玻璃板两边的氢气密度相等，设在化学反应过程中，氢气压强的减小可忽略不计，设玻璃板的质量为 m ，有关几何量如热图 3.2.1 所示。

观察到玻璃板绕它的坚直轴转过一个很小的角度 α 后，处于平衡状态，试求 α 的大小，

question: 如热图 3.3.1 所示，在真空中有一个质量为 $M$ 的试管，它被质量为 $m$ 的隔板等分为两部分。隔板封闭的那部分有质量为 $n \mathrm{~mol}$ ，温度为 $T$ ，摩尔质量为 $\mu$ 的单原子分子理想气体。放开隔板后，隔板无摩擦地直立向上移动，在隔板离开试管顶端后气体方始从试管逸出，设隔板开始运动时，试管静止。试求试管的最终速度。
subject: TSM

question: 如热图 4.6.1 所示，有一总长度为 $L$ ，粗细均匀的 $U$ 形毛细管，将它的两个开口端坚直向下稍稍浸入两个容器的等高液面之中，因毛细作用，液体 1 和液体 2 分别在毛细管中上升了 $h_{1}$ 和 $h_{2}$ 的高度，设液体 1 和 2 的密度分别为 $\rho_{1}$ 和 $\rho_{2}$ ，它们与毛细管壁的接触角均为 $0^{\text{°}}$ ，设液体在毛细管中上升时管内气体无外漏，大气压强为 $p_{0}$ 。试求液体 1 与液体 2 的表面张力系数的比值

All variables are labeled; fluid columns and heights are vertically aligned, and the direction of $h_1$ and $h_2$ is upwards from the interfaces to the gas region.

question: 如电图1．14．1 所示，在半径为 $R$ ，质量为 $m$ 且均匀分布的细圆环上，均匀地分布着总电量为 $q$ 的正电荷。在通过圆环中心 $O$ 点且垂直于圆环平面的 $x$ 轴上有两个固定的点电荷，它们分别在圆环的两侧，与环心的距离均为 $L$ ，各带有电量为 $Q$ 的正电荷。设圆环只能沿 $x$ 轴平动，显然，在上述条件下，圆环处于平衡位置。若该位置是稳定平衡位置，试求圆环在其附近做微小振动的周期。
subject: EM

Two point charges, each with charge $Q$, are symmetrically placed at positions $x = -L$ and $x = +L$ along the $x$-axis. The $x$-axis is shown with an arrow indicating the positive direction.

question: 如电图1.19.1 所示，两个固定的均匀带电球面 A 和 B 分别带电 $4 Q$ 和 $Q(Q$ $>0)$ 。两球心之间的距离 $d$ 远大于两球的半径，两球心的连线 $M N$ 与两球面的相交处都开有足够小的孔，因小孔而损失的电量可以忽略不计。一个带负电的质点静止地放置在 A 球左侧某处 $P$ 点，且在 $M N$ 直线上。设质点从 $P$ 点释放后刚好能穿越三个小孔，并通过 B 球球心。试求质点开始时所在的 $P$ 点与 A 球球心的距离 $x$ 应为多少？
subject: EM

question: 如电图 1.29.1 所示，三根等长的带电绝缘细棒首尾相接构成三角形，其中电荷的分布如同绝缘棒都换成等长导体棒且已达到静电平衡时的电荷分布，测得电图1.29.1 中中 $A$ 点和 $B$ 点的电势分别为 $U_{A}$ 和 $U_{B}$ 。假设若将 $a b$ 棒取走，并不影响 $a c$ 及 $b c$ 两棒的电荷分布，试求此时 $A$ 点和 $B$ 点的电势，
subject: EM

question: 如电图1.2.1 所示，在边长为 $a$ 的正方形的四个顶点分别有电量均为 $Q$ 的固定的点电荷。在正方形对角线交点上放置一个质量为 $m$ ，电量为 $q$（ $q$ 与 $Q$ 同号）的自由点电荷。今将 $q$ 沿某一对角线移动一个很小的距离，试问：$q$ 是否将做周期性振动？若是，试求出振动周期。

question: 如电图 1.30 .1 所示，恒温的矩形箱内装有理想气体，当隔板将箱等分为二时，两侧气体压强均为 $P_{0}$ 。当隔板平行移动时，无摩擦，不漏气，两侧气体经历准静态过程。隔板是面积为 $A$ 的金属板，带电量为 $Q$ ，矩形箱上与它平行的两块板也是金属板，面积也为 $A$ ，相距为 $2 L$ ，固定，并接地。隔板两侧的电场均匀。箱的其余部分是不导电的绝缘板。试求隔板的平衡位置。

question: 如电图 1.31.1 所示，在半径为 $R$ 的接地金属圆柱面的中央放有一根半径为 $r_{0}$ 的同轴细长导线，导线处于正的高电势 $U_{0}$ 。于是导线外侧附近介质原子被电离成自由电子与正离子，其中自由电子即被导线吸附，正离子则离开导线径向地运动。设正离子的径向迁移率（径向速度与电场强度的比值）为常数 $w$ ，且迁移过程中正离子始终围绕导线形成均匀的圆柱形薄层。 2.设全部正离子电量为 $Q$ ，为了使导线电势保持原来的 $U_{0}$不变，需给导线补充电量 $Q^{*}$ 。试导出 $Q^{*}$ 与时间 $t$ 的关系。
subject: EM

question: 如电图1．33．1 所示，两块足够大的接地导体平板 A 和 B 平行坚直放置，相距 $2 d, d=10 \text{~cm}$ 。在两板之间的中间位置，用长 $l=1 \text{~m}$ 的绝缘细线悬挂一个质量 $m=0.1 \text{~g}$ ，电量 $q=5 \times 10^{-9} \text{C}$ 的小摆球。让小摆球稍稍偏离平衡位置后释放，使之小角度摆动。忽略各种电磁阻尼和空气阻力。试求小球的摆动周期 $T$ 。

question: 如电图1.3.1 所示，在 $x$ 轴的 $a$ 处分别有两个固定的点电荷，它们的电量均为 $Q(Q>0)$。在 $x$ 轴的 $2a$ 处分别有另外两个固定的点电荷，它们的电量均为 $-8Q$。在原点 $O$ 有一个电量为 $q(q>0)$，质量为 $m$ 的带电质点。设带电质点只能在 $x$ 轴上运动，试分析带电质点所在的平衡位置原点 $O$，是否为稳定平衡位置，若原点 $O$ 为稳定平衡位置，将带电质点移到 $x=A$ 处从静止释放 $(0<A<a)$，试求其振动周期。

question: 如电图 2.16.1 所示，在螺绕环的平均半径 $R$ 处有点源 $P$ ，从 $P$ 点沿磁力线方向注入小孔径角为 $2 \alpha_{0}\left(\alpha_{0} \ll 1^{\circ}\right)$ 的电子束，束中电子都是经电压 $U_{0}$ 加速从 $P$ 点出发的。设绕环中磁场 $B$ 的大小为常量，电子束中各电子间的相互作用可以忽略。为了使电子束沿环形磁场运动，需要另外加一个使电子束偏转的均匀磁场 $B_{1}$ ，对于在环内沿半径为 $R$ 的圆形轨道运动的一个电子，试计算所需的 $B_{1}$ 的大小。
subject: EM

question: 如电图 2.16.1 所示，在螺绕环的平均半径 $R$ 处有点源 $P$ ，从 $P$ 点沿磁力线方向注入小孔径角为 $2 \alpha_{0}\left(\alpha_{0} \ll 1^{\circ}\right)$ 的电子束，束中电子都是经电压 $U_{0}$ 加速从 $P$ 点出发的。设绕环中磁场 $B$ 的大小为常量，电子束中各电子间的相互作用可以忽略。当电子束沿环形磁场运动时，为了使电子束绕一圈有四个聚焦点，即如电图 2.16 .1 所示，每绕过 $\pi / 2$ 的圆周角聚焦一次，试问：$B$ 应为多大？（此处可忽略 $\boldsymbol{B}_{1}$ ，并可忽略磁场 $\boldsymbol{B}$ 的弯曲。）

question: 在外磁场中的超导体，平衡后超导体内部的磁感应强度处处为零，超导体表面外侧的磁感应强度与表面平行。在如电图 2.24.1 所示 $O x y z$ 直角坐标系中，$x y$ 平面是水平面，其中有一超导平板，$z$ 轴竖直向上，超导平板在 $z=0$ 处，在 $z=h$ 处有一质量为 $m$ ，半径为 $r$ ，环心在 $z$ 轴上，环平面为水平面的匀质金属圆环，且 $r$ $\text{gg} h$ 。在圆环内通以稳恒电流，刚好使圆环漂浮在 $z=h$ 处，试求圆环中的电流强度。

Coordinate axes $x$, $y$, and $z$ are shown with positive directions indicated by arrows.

question: 在外磁场中的超导体，平衡后超导体内部的磁感应强度处处为零，超导体表面外侧的磁感应强度与表面平行。在如电图 2.24.1 所示 $O x y z$ 直角坐标系中，$x y$ 平面是水平面，其中有一超导平板，$z$ 轴竖直向上，超导平板在 $z=0$ 处，在 $z=h$ 处有一质量为 $m$ ，半径为 $r$ ，环心在 $z$ 轴上，环平面为水平面的匀质金属圆环，且 $r$ $\text{gg} h$ 。在圆环内通以稳恒电流，刚好使圆环漂浮在 $z=h$ 处，若使圆环保持水平，从平衡位置稍稍偏上或偏下，则圆环将上，下振动。试求振动周期 $T_{1}$ 。

question: 在外磁场中的超导体，平衡后超导体内部的磁感应强度处处为零，超导体表面外侧的磁感应强度与表面平行。在如电图 2.24.1 所示 $O x y z$ 直角坐标系中，$x y$ 平面是水平面，其中有一超导平板，$z$ 轴竖直向上，超导平板在 $z=0$ 处，在 $z=h$ 处有一质量为 $m$ ，半径为 $r$ ，环心在 $z$ 轴上，环平面为水平面的匀质金属圆环，且 $r$ $\text{gg} h$ 。在圆环内通以稳恒电流，刚好使圆环漂浮在 $z=h$ 处，当圆环处在平衡位置时，其中与 $x$ 轴平行的直径标为 $P_{1} P_{2}$ ，与 $y$ 轴平行的直径标为 $Q_{1} Q_{2}$ 。若保持 $P_{1} P_{2}$ 不动，使圆环绕 $P_{1} P_{2}$ 稍有倾斜，即使 $Q_{1} Q_{2}$ 与 $y$ 轴有很小的夹角，则圆环将以 $P_{1} P_{2}$ 为轴摆动。试求摆动周期 $T_{2}$ 。

Coordinate axes $x$, $y$, and $z$ are indicated with positive direction arrows.

question: 磁流体发电机的工作原理如电图 3.10.1 所示。横截面为矩形的管道长为 $l$，宽为 $a$，高为 $b$，上、下两个侧面是绝缘体，相距为 $a$ 的两个侧面是电阻可略的导体，这两个侧面与负载电阻 $R_{L}$ 相连。整个管道处于匀强磁场区域，$\boldsymbol{B}$ 垂直于上、下侧面指向上。管道内沿长度方向流有电阻率为 $\rho$ 的电离气体，气体流速处处相同，所受摩擦阻力的大小与流速成正比。现在管的两端维持恒定的压强差 $p$，无磁场存在时气体的流速为 $v_{0}$。试求有磁场存在时，此发电机的电动势 $\mathcal{E}$。
subject: EM

Diagram shows an equilateral triangle with vertices labeled $A$, $B$, and $C$, each connected by sides of length $a$. Inside the triangle, a uniform magnetic field $\vec{B}$ is represented by dots (field directed out of the page). question: 如电图 3.12.1 所示，由铜质细导线弯成的半径为 $a$ 的圆形圈和一内接等边三角形电阻丝构成的电路，电路中各段电阻值已在电图 3.12.1 中标明。在圆形圈所在平面内有垂直纸面向里的铜强磁场 $B, B$ 随时间 $t$ 均匀地减小，其变化率的大小为已知常量 $k$ ，设 $2 r_{1}=3 r_{2}$ 。试求电图 3.12.1 中 $A, B$ 两点之间的电势差 $U_{A B}$ 。

Points $A$, $B$, and $C$ label the triangle's vertices, and all radii are marked.

question: 如电图 3.1.1 所示，在边长为 $a$ 的等边三角形区域内有匀强磁场 $B$，其方向垂直纸面向外。一个边长也为 $a$ 的等边三角形导体框架 $ABC$，在 $t=0$ 时恰好与上述磁场区域的边界重合，尔后以周期 $T$ 绕其中心在纸面内顺时针方向匀速转动，于是在框架 $ABC$ 中产生感应电流。规定电流按 $ABCA$ 方向流动时电流强度取正值，反方向流动时取负值。设框架 $ABC$ 的电阻为 $R$。试求从 $t=0$ 到 $t_{1}=T/6$ 时间内的平均电流强度 $\bar{I}_{1}$ 和从 $t=0$ 到 $t_{2}=T/2$ 时间内的平均电流强度 $\bar{I}_{2}$。
subject: EM
caption:
IMAGE 1:

question:
如果存在磁荷（磁单极子），那么在对磁荷量 $q_{\mathrm{m}}$ 的单位作适当定义后，真空中麦克斯韦方程组的微分形式应补充修改为下述形式：
$$
\left\{
\begin{array}{l}
\nabla \cdot \boldsymbol{E} = \frac{\rho}{\varepsilon_{0}} \\
\nabla \cdot \boldsymbol{B} = \frac{\rho_{\mathrm{m}}}{\mu_{0}} \\
\nabla \times \boldsymbol{E} = -\frac{\partial \boldsymbol{B}}{\partial t} - \frac{1}{\mu_{0}} \boldsymbol{j}_{\mathrm{m}} \\
\nabla \times \boldsymbol{B} = \mu_{0} \varepsilon_{0} \frac{\partial \boldsymbol{E}}{\partial t} + \mu_{0} \boldsymbol{j}
\end{array}
\right.
$$

式中：$\rho$ 和 $\boldsymbol{j}$ 分别为电荷密度和电流密度；$\rho_{\mathrm{m}}$ 和 $\boldsymbol{j}_{\mathrm{m}}$ 分别为磁荷密度和磁流密度。

为了寻找磁荷，物理学家设计了如电图 5.19.1 所示的实验。图中，由 $n$ 匝线圈和电量计或电流表 G 构成回路。让可能带有磁荷 $q_{\mathrm{m}}$ 的物质碎块连续 $N$ 次通过线圈，若 $q_{\mathrm{m}} \neq 0$，则在线圈中会形成可以测出的电流。

设线圈用超导材料制成，即 $R$ 可略，而 $L$ 不可略，且开始时线圈内无电流。试问：$q_{\mathrm{m}}$ 经线圈环行 $N$ 周后，线圈中的电流 $I$ 为多大？
subject: EM
caption:
IMAGE 1:
A circular loop of wire with $n$ turns is connected in series to a galvanometer (G); a magnetic charge $q_m$ is shown moving counterclockwise through the loop, as indicated by the arrow.

question:
在海洋中，声波的速度随深度、温度和含盐量变化。已知声速随深度变化的规律如力图7.35.1所示，最小声速$v_0$出现在海洋表面和海底之间。以最小声速作为坐标原点，$z_s$和$z_b$分别表示海洋表面和海底的坐标，则声速$v$与$z$的关系为
$$
v(z)=\begin{cases}
v_0 + b z, & z>0 \\
v_0, & z=0 \\
v_0 - b z, & z<0
\end{cases}
$$
式中$b$为正的常量。在$x=0,z=0$处放置声源$S$，声波传播方向用初始发射角$\theta_0$表示。设在$Ox$轴上$x=X$处设置接收器$H$，试导出能直接到达接收器的声波对应的$\theta_0$公式（排除经反射的情形）。

question: 如热图2.11.1 所示为两个底面积均为 $S=100 \text{ cm}^2$ 的圆筒。左筒内气体的质量 $M_{\text{左}}=4 \text{ g}$ ，体积 $V_{\text{左}}=22.4 \text{ L}$ ，压强 $p_{\text{左}}=1 \text{ atm}$ ，温度 $T_{\text{左}}=273 \text{ K}$ 。右筒内有同种气体，质定的 $0^{\text{o}} \text{C}$ 的温度。整个系统在真空中，放开左，右筒相连的活塞后，活塞移动了 $l=50 \text{ cm}$ 后达到平衡而静止。试问：右筒内的气体吸收了多少热量？已知气体可视为理想气体，其定容比热为 $c_{V}=0.75 \text{ cal}^{*} /(\text{g} \text{ K})=3.14 \text{ J} /(\text{g} \text{ K})$ ，设活塞与筒壁之间无摩擦。

question: 如热图 2.8.1 所示为一固定的直立气缸，它由上，下两个相互连通的圆筒构成。上部圆筒的体积为 $V_{\mathrm{m}}$ ，其中有一个质量为 $2 m$ ，面积为 $2 S$ 的薄活塞 A。下部圆筒足够长，其中有一个质量为 $m$ ，面积为 $S$ 的活塞 B。两圆筒由一细而短的管道连通，两活塞均可在各自的圆筒内无摩擦地上下滑动，活塞 A 的上方盛有 1 mol 的理想气体，活塞 $\mathrm{A}, \mathrm{B}$ 之间盛有某种气体，活塞 B下方与大气连通，开始时整个系统处于平衡态， A 上方理想气体的温度为 $T_{0}$ ，已知该理想气体每摩尔的内能 $U=C T$ ，其中 $C$为常量,$T$ 为热力学温度，活塞 B下方的大气压强为常量 $p_{0}$ ，设气缸壁，管道，活塞均不导热。然后，通过置于上部圆筒顶端的电热丝 $L$ 对活塞 A 上方的气体缓慢加热，设在整个加热过程中传递给 A 上方气体的热量为 $Q_{0}$ 。试问：达到平衡时， A 上方气体的温度 $T_{\mathrm{f}}$ 是多少？

question: In the scheme of a Denisyuk hologram recording, a laser beam is incident on the photographic plate P and the scattering object $S$ at the angle $\alpha_{0}=45 \mathrm{deg}$ to the normal to the photographic plate and the object surface. The wave scattered by the surface of the object propagates along the normal to the surface of the photographic plate, meets the incident wave, and forms a standing wave. Determine the period $\Lambda$ of the standing wave in the photosensitive layer with refractive index $n=1.4$ if the wavelength of the laser beam is $\lambda_{0}=633 \mathrm{~nm}$.
subject: OPT
caption:
IMAGE 1:
A collimated light beam is incident at angle $\alpha_0$ onto a phase grating with groove spacing $\Lambda$, placed in region P; the resulting diffracted beams exit the grating at various angles, with one directed toward a detector labeled S. All incident and diffracted light rays are shown as straight solid arrows indicating their directions.

question: Plot the ratio of amplitudes for the refracted (evanescent) wave and the incident wave $E_{2} / E_{0}$ versus distance $z$ from the boundary between two dielectric media with $n_{1}=1.5$ and $n_{2}=1.0$ under the conditions of total internal reflection of light, with $\lambda_{0}=550 \mathrm{~nm}$ incident on the angle $\alpha_{0}=45 \mathrm{deg}$. Determine the angle of incidence $\alpha_{0}$ at which the evanescent wave amplitude decreases by the factor of $e^{-1}$ at a distance $z=\lambda_{0} / 2$.
subject: OPT
caption:
IMAGE 1:
A planar interface at $z = 0$ separates two media with refractive indices $n_1$ (for $z > 0$) and $n_2$ (for $z < 0$); an incident electromagnetic wave with electric field amplitude $E_0$ approaches from region $n_1$ at angle $\alpha_0$, while field $E_2$ is present in region $n_2$; propagation directions are indicated by arrows, with the $x, y$ axes in the plane of the interface and the $z$ axis perpendicular to it.

question: A linearly polarized wave with wavelength $\lambda_{0}=0.55 \mu \mathrm{~m}$ and direction of the electric field strength vector $\vec{E}_{i}$ forms angle $\theta=30 \mathrm{deg}$ with the optical axis of the plate $\mathrm{O}-\mathrm{O}^{\prime}$, parallel to its input face, and is incident on a uniaxial crystal plate with thickness $d=6.9 \mu \mathrm{~m}$ and the principal values of the refractive index $n_{o}=1.56$ and $n_{e}=1.6$. Determine the phase difference $\Delta \phi_{o e}$ between the ordinary and extraordinary waves emerging from the plate; also determine the polarization state and the parameters of the emerging wave.
subject: OPT
caption:
IMAGE 1:
Two diagrams showing: (left) a rectangular slab of thickness $d$ with faces labeled $O$ and $O'$, subjected to an incident electric field $\vec{E}_i$ directed horizontally from left to right; (right) a circular cross-section of the slab with the same $O$ and $O'$ labeling, illustrating the electric field $\vec{E}_i$ entering at an angle $\theta$ relative to the normal (dashed line) through the slab. Vector $\vec{E}_i$ and angle $\theta$ are both explicitly marked.

question: Determine angle $\beta$ between the orthogonally polarized rays emerging from a Rochon prism made of Iceland spar ($n_{o}=1.658, n_{e}=1.486$) with angle $\alpha=20$ deg between the leg and hypotenuse faces of the prism.
subject: OPT
caption:
IMAGE 1:
A beam enters a rectangular region, forming an angle $\alpha$ with the surface, and then moves through a uniform field indicated by parallel dashed/dotted lines inside the region. Within the region, the beam's path bends, forming an angle $\beta$ with the surface upon exit. Vector arrows beside the beam's exit indicate the direction and nature of deflection.

question: Determine the intensity ratio $I_{o} / I_{e}$ of, and the angle $\beta$ between the orthogonally polarized rays emerging from a Senarmont prism made of Iceland spar ($n_{o}=1.658, n_{e}=1.486$) with angle $\alpha=20$ deg between the leg and hypotenuse faces of the prism. The incident ray is linearly polarized with polarization azimuth $\theta=60 \mathrm{deg}$ with respect to the optical axis of the second half of the prism. Ignore the reflection of light at the boundaries.
subject: OPT
caption:
IMAGE 1:
A light ray enters a rectangular glass slab at an incident angle $\alpha$, refracts through the slab, and emerges at an angle $\beta$ into air; arrows indicate the direction of the light propagation, with angles $\alpha$ (incidence) and $\beta$ (emergence) labeled relative to the surface normal.

question: A beam of linearly polarized light with intensity $I_{i}$ and wavelength $\nabla_{0}$ is passed through a half-wave retarder plate and then through a Wollaston prism. The plate rotates in its own plane with angular velocity $\nabla$. Derive the equations describing the time dependence of the intensity of the ordinary $I_{o}(t)$ and extraordinary $I_{e}(t)$ waves at the prism output.
subject: OPT
caption:
IMAGE 1:
A polarized light beam enters a birefringent crystal slab (shaded rectangle), splitting into ordinary ($o$) and extraordinary ($e$) rays at both entrance and exit faces; arrows indicate polarization direction, lines show ray paths, and angle $\beta$ denotes the optical axis orientation relative to the initial ray direction; $O-O'$ labels the path of the incident and refracted beam bundle.

question: Electric voltage $U$ is applied to a Kerr cell with nitrobenzene placed between crossed polarizers $\text{P}_{1}$ and $\text{P}_{2}$. The distance between the capacitor plates of the cell is $d=1 \text{ mm}$, the length $l$ of the capacitor is 6.4 cm, and the Kerr constant is $K=2.2 \times 10^{-12} \text{ m} / \text{V}^{2}$. The transmission axes of the polarizers form angle $\text{α}=45 \text{ deg}$ with the plates of the condenser. Determine intensity $I_{2}$ of light output from the system in this case if the beam of natural light with intensity $I_{i}=0.06 \text{ mW} / \text{mm}^{2}$ is passed through the first linear polarizer $\text{P}_{1}$.
subject: OPT
caption:
IMAGE 1:
Two schematic views of an electronic device are shown: 
- In both the side and top views, two parallel plates $P_1$ and $P_2$ are separated by distance $l$ and connected to a voltage source $U$ ($+$ at the top, $-$ at the bottom), forming a region where a uniform electric field is present.
- Currents $I_1$ and $I_2$ enter and exit horizontally on either side.
- In the top view, the rectangular region between $P_1$ and $P_2$ is circumscribed by a circle of diameter $d$, centering the electrodes, visually specifying the spatial boundary of the cross-section.
- All currents and electric field vectors are depicted pointing from left to right and from lower to upper potential, respectively.

question: A plane wave of natural (randomly polarized) light is incident on the boundary between air and quartz. The angle of incidence is $\alpha_{0}=45 \mathrm{deg}$. The optical axis of the quartz crystal $\mathrm{O}-\mathrm{O}^{\prime}$ is perpendicular to the plane of incidence of the wave. Determine the angle $\Delta \alpha_{2}$ between the propagation directions of the ordinary and extraordinary waves in the crystal if the velocities of their propagations are $v_{2 o}=1.943 \cdot 10^{8} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$ and $v_{2 e}=1.932 \cdot 10^{8} \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$, respectively, and the air refractive index is $n_{1}=1.0$.
subject: OPT
caption:
IMAGE 1:
A light ray incident from medium with refractive index $n_1$ strikes the interface at angle $\alpha_0$ to the normal (dashed line), enters a second medium with indices $n_{2o}$ and $n_{2z}$ labeled alongside a point $O - O'$, where after refraction, the outgoing ray deviates by angle $\Delta\alpha_2$ from its original path; all vectors indicate ray directions.

question: A beam of natural (randomly polarized) light with aperture diameter $D=4 \text{ mm}$ is incident at the angle $\theta_{0}=45$ deg onto the face of a plane-parallel plate of Iceland spar ($n_{o}=1.658$, $n_{e}=1.486$) in air ($n_{1} \thickapprox 1.0$). The optical axis of the crystal $\text{O}-\text{O}^{\text{'}}$ is perpendicular to the plane of incidence. Determine the minimal thickness $d$ of the plate for which the ordinary and extraordinary light beams output from the plate would not overlap.
subject: OPT
caption:
IMAGE 1:
A parallel beam of light with incident angle $\alpha_0$ and separation $D$ enters a transparent rectangular slab of thickness $d$ at points labeled $O$ and $O'$. Upon emergence, the beam splits into two rays labeled $e$ (extraordinary) and $o$ (ordinary), each indicated with arrows showing their propagation directions.

question: Two linearly polarized monochromatic waves with wavelengths $\lambda_{1}=\lambda_{2}=0.63 \mu \mathrm{~m}$ propagate at an angle $\theta=45 \mathrm{deg}$ to each other. Photosensitive plate P is placed perpendicular to the propagation direction of one of the waves. Determine the resolution $R$ [lines $/ \mathrm{mm}$ ] of the photosensitive plate required for recording the pattern of arising interference fringes.
subject: OPT
caption:
IMAGE 1:
Diagram shows two linearly polarized light beams with electric field vectors $\vec{E}_1$ and $\vec{E}_2$ intersecting at an angle $\theta$ before encountering a polarizer (labeled P); all vector directions and $\theta$ are explicitly indicated.

question: Determine the period $\Lambda$ of the interference pattern in an experiment with a Fresnel biprism in air. The refractive index of the prism is $n=1.5$, the wavelength is $\lambda_{0}=0.6 \mu \mathrm{~m}$, and the refracting angle of the prism is $\alpha=170 \mathrm{deg}$.
subject: OPT
caption:
IMAGE 1:
A parallel beam of light rays (horizontal arrows) is incident from the left on a prism, shown as a gray transparent object, with apex angle $\alpha$ labeled; outgoing rays (arrows) are refracted at both prism surfaces and emerge on the right at angles to the original direction.

question: Two monochromatic-light point sources $S_{1}$ and $S_{2}$ with similar wavelengths $\\lambda$ are positioned on the $z$ axis with separation $\\Delta z$ between them, and they illuminate a screen located perpendicular to the $z$ axis at distance $z_{1}$ from source $\\mathrm{S}_{1}$. Derive an equation for the distribution of intensity $I(x, y)$ in the interference pattern on the screen in the paraxial region $\\sqrt{x^{2}+y^{2}} \\ll z_{1}$. The intensities of the light waves from the sources in the plane of the screen are equal to $I_{1}$ and $I_{2}$.
subject: OPT
caption:
IMAGE 1:
Diagram shows a two-source interference setup: two point sources labeled $S_1$ and $S_2$ are separated by a distance $\Delta z$ along the $z$-axis; both emit waves propagating toward a screen, located a distance $z_1$ from $S_1$, with arrows indicating the direction of wave travel. The right panel shows a contour plot in the $x$-$y$ plane on the screen with concentric fringes centered at the origin, corresponding to intensity patterns from the interference. Coordinate axes $x$, $y$, and $z$ are labeled throughout.

question: Two plane monochromatic waves with different wavelengths $\lambda_{1}=630 \mathrm{~nm}$ and $\lambda_{2}=631.1 \mathrm{~nm}$ are superimposed at angle $\theta=0.05 \mathrm{deg}$. Determine the frequency $f$ of the intensity oscillations in a single point on the screen, the period $\Lambda$, and the velocity $v$ of the motion of interference fringes observed on the screen P placed perpendicularly to the bisector of angle $\theta$.
subject: OPT
caption:
IMAGE 1:
Two parallel light rays, labeled $\lambda_1$ and $\lambda_2$, enter from the left at an angle $\theta$ relative to the normal of a vertical opaque barrier with a slit at point $P$ (with axes $x$ and $y$ defined at the slit). On the right, a second vertical barrier at position $\Lambda$ contains an observation screen represented by a circle, with axes $x$ and $y$, and a velocity vector $\vec{v}$ pointing horizontally in the positive $x$-direction.

question: Determine the optical path difference $\Delta_{12}$ in an airfilled Michelson interferometer with arms having geometric lengths $L_{1}$ and $L_{2}$. What will be the variation $\delta \Delta_{12}$ of this path length difference if a glass plate with thickness $d$ and refractive index $n$ is placed inside one of the interferometer arms?
subject: OPT
caption:
IMAGE 1:
Diagram of a Michelson interferometer: a beam splitter (BS) divides incident beams into two perpendicular arms with optical paths $L_1$ and $L_2$, each terminated by mirrors $M_1$ and $M_2$ respectively; a transparent plate of thickness $d$ and refractive index $n$ is placed in arm $L_2$; arrows indicate beam directions throughout the setup.

question: A monochromatic-light point source $S$ with wavelength $\\lambda_{0}$ is used in a Michelson interferometer. The distance between the source and the beam splitter BS is $L_{0}$. The distances between the beam splitter and the mirrors of the interferometer are $L_{1}$ and $L_{2}$. Write the equation for the phase difference $\\Delta \\phi_{12}(x, y)$ of the light waves as a function of the coordinates $(x, y)$ at the output screen of the interferometer installed at distance $L$ from the beam splitter. Use the paraxial approximation for the light rays that hit the screen.
subject: OPT
caption:
IMAGE 1:
Diagram of a Michelson interferometer: a light source S emits a beam along the $L_0$ path toward a beam splitter (BS) centered at the origin of the $x$-$z$ plane; the beam splits, traveling distance $L_1$ toward mirror $M_1$ in the $z$-direction and distance $L_2$ toward mirror $M_2$ along the $x$-direction; reflected beams recombine producing an interference pattern (concentric rings) in the $xy$-plane at the detector; $\Delta L$ denotes the path length difference between the two arms. Vectors and axes ($x$, $y$, $z$) are indicated as shown.

question: The light from two mutually coherent sources $S_{1}$ and $S_{2}$ gives rise to a system of interference fringes on the screen P, separated from the plane of the sources by the distance $z=2.5 \text{ m}$. By how many times $\beta$ will the spatial period $\text{Λ}$ of the interference fringes change if between the sources and the screen P a focusing lens L with focal length $f=50 \text{ cm}$ is placed so that the sources will appear in the front focal plane of the lens?
subject: OPT
caption:
IMAGE 1:
Two point sources $S_1$ and $S_2$ are positioned vertically along a line on the left, separated by a distance (not labeled), and emit light towards a converging lens $L$ located a distance $f$ away; the lens is oriented with its principal axis horizontal. A screen $P$ is placed a distance $z$ from the sources, to the right of the lens, parallel to their plane. Distances $f$ and $z$ are indicated with arrows and labels.

question: A quasi-collimated beam of white visible light is passed through a bandpass filter BPF with central transmission wavelength $\lambda_{02} \approx 650 \mathrm{~nm}$ and transmission spectral bandwidth $\Delta \lambda_{02} \approx 50 \mathrm{~nm}$. Determine the ratio $\beta$ of temporal coherence lengths of the filtered $l_{c 2}$ and the initial $l_{c 1}$ beams of light, $\beta=l_{c 2} / l_{c 1}$.
subject: OPT
caption:
IMAGE 1:
Two parallel horizontal lines carry rightward-directed arrows, representing optical signals incident on a band-pass filter (BPF) placed between them; above each line is a plot of normalized spectral intensity $G(\lambda)$ versus wavelength $\lambda$: the left plot shows a signal with central wavelength $\lambda_{01}$ and bandwidth $\Delta\lambda_1$, while the right plot shows two overlapping spectra with centers $\lambda_{01}$, $\lambda_{02}$ and bandwidth $\Delta\lambda_2$.

question: Determine the temporal coherence length $l_{c}$ and the longitudinal coherence length $L_{c}$ of such a field with mean wavelength $\lambda_{0} \approx 0.65 \mu \mathrm{~m}$ and spectral width $\Delta \lambda \approx 0.001 \mu \mathrm{~m}$ at distance $z=80 \mathrm{~mm}$ from a round spatially incoherent light source with diameter $D=20 \mathrm{~mm}$.
subject: OPT
caption:
IMAGE 1:
A source $S$ emits rays along the $z$-axis; two outgoing rays are shown making angles $2\theta$ with each other, intersecting the $z$-axis at points $P_1$ and $P_2$ separated by a distance $L_c$ along the $x$-axis; axes $x$, $y$, and $z$ are labeled indicating the spatial orientation.

question: The coherence of an optical field in the longitudinal direction, i.e., in the direction of the light propagation, is equally dependent on the parameters of the frequency and the angular spectra of the field. This may lead to a reduction of the longitudinal coherence length of the field $L_{c}$ as compared to the temporal coherence length $l_{c}$, determined by the frequency spectrum width $\\Delta \\lambda$, and as compared to the spatial coherence length $\\rho_{c z}$, determined by the width of the angular spectrum $2 \\theta$ of the field. Plot the longitudinal coherence length $L_{c}(z)$ of the field versus the distance $z$ from an extended spatially incoherent light source $S$ having a round shape with diameter $D=5 \\mathrm{~mm}$. The source radiates the light with mean wavelength $\\lambda_{0} \\approx 0.55 \\mu \\mathrm{~m}$ and frequency spectral width $\\Delta \\lambda \\approx 0.02 \\mu \\mathrm{~m}$. Determine the temporal length $l_{c}$ and the longitudinal coherence length $L_{c}$ at distance $z=$ 9.3 mm from the light source.
subject: OPT
caption:
IMAGE 1:
A source $S$ of width $D$ emits radiation directed at an angle $2\theta$ about the $z$-axis; at distance $L_c$ from the source, the angular spread defines an illuminated region on the $z$-axis. Variables $D$, $2\theta$, $z$, and $L_c$ are labeled; arrows indicate beam directions.

question: Determine the longitudinal coherence length $L_{c}$ of an optical field from a spatially incoherent light source in the back focal plane $\text{F}^{\text{'}}$ of a collecting lens L and in the plane of the real image of the source $\text{S}^{\text{'}}$. The source S is located at distance $z_{1}=160 \text{ mm}$ from the front focal plane F of lens L and radiates light with mean wavelength $\text{λ}_{0} \text{≈} 0.55 \text{ μm}$ and frequency spectrum width $\text{Δλ} \text{≈} 0.002 \text{ μm}$. The transverse size of the source is $D_{s}=4 \text{ mm}$, the diameter of the lens aperture is $D_{a}=40 \text{ mm}$, and the focal length of the lens is $f=80 \text{ mm}$. Determine the longitudinal coherence length $L_{c}$ for the back focal plane of the lens.
subject: OPT
caption:
IMAGE 1:
A wedge-shaped thin film (W) of varying thickness is placed between two flat plates (P); parallel straight lines represent incident light rays directed perpendicularly toward the wedge. The side view (left) shows multiple reflected light rays, while the top view (right) shows a series of alternating bright and dark horizontal interference fringes within the wedge boundaries.

question: Determine the longitudinal coherence length $L_{c}$ of an optical field from a spatially incoherent light source in the back focal plane $\text{F}^{\text{'}}$ of a collecting lens L and in the plane of the real image of the source $\text{S}^{\text{'}}$. The source S is located at distance $z_{1}=160 \text{ mm}$ from the front focal plane F of lens L and radiates light with mean wavelength $\text{λ}_{0} \text{≈} 0.55 \text{ μm}$ and frequency spectrum width $\text{Δλ} \text{≈} 0.002 \text{ μm}$. The transverse size of the source is $D_{s}=4 \text{ mm}$, the diameter of the lens aperture is $D_{a}=40 \text{ mm}$, and the focal length of the lens is $f=80 \text{ mm}$. Determine the longitudinal coherence length $L_{c}$ for the plane of the light source image.
subject: OPT
caption:
IMAGE 1:
The diagram shows parallel incident rays (arrows) passing through a wedge-shaped transparent film $W$ situated in front of a flat plate $P$. On the right, the front view depicts interference fringes (dark and light bands) formed within the region of the wedge $W$ bordered by the plate $P$. The direction of the incident rays is indicated as left to right.

question: In a Rayleigh interferometer studying transparent media, a slit-illuminated by primary extended light source $S_{1}$ with central wavelength $\\lambda_{0}=0.55 \\mu \\mathrm{~m}$-is used as a secondary light source $\\mathbf{S}_{2}$. Determine the maximal width $b$ of slit $\\mathbf{S}_{2}$ (sufficient for observation of interference fringes in the image of the slit $S_{2}^{\\prime}$ ) if the focal length of the first lens $L_{1}$ of the interferometer is $f_{1}=40 \\mathrm{~cm}$ and the separation between the slits is $d=20 \\mathrm{~mm}$.
subject: OPT
caption:
IMAGE 1:
A schematic diagram showing a double-path optical setup: light from a source is split into two beams at slits $S_1$ and $S_2$, passes through lenses $L_1$, then through cuvette 1 (upper path) and cuvette 2 (lower path), recombines with additional lenses $L_1'$ at points $S'_2$, and forms interference patterns seen by the observer's eye through an ocular lens; all optical components and interference pattern positions are labeled.

question: In a Michelson interferometer with an extended quasi-monochromatic light source S with mean wavelength $\lambda_{0}=0.6 \mu \mathrm{~m}$, one of the plane mirrors is tilted at a small angle $\alpha=5 \cdot 10^{-4} \mathrm{rad}$. The mirrors are located at equal distances $z_{1}=z_{2}$ from the beam splitter BS. The interference fringe pattern is observed in the plane of mirror images $x, y$, obtained with unit magnification $\beta=1$ using a focusing lens $L$ with focal length $f=80 \mathrm{~mm}$. Determine the period $\Lambda$ of the interference fringes in the plane of the interferometer mirror images and the extension (depth) $\Delta z$ of the domain of localization of fringes if the diameter of the aperture diaphragm of the lens is $D=10 \mathrm{~mm}$. Assume that the aperture diaphragm of lens L serves as a secondary extended light source for the whole domain where the fringes are localized.
subject: OPT
caption:
IMAGE 1:
Diagram of an optical interferometer: a source $S$ emits light towards a beam splitter BS, which splits the beam toward mirrors $M_1$ and $M_2$; $M_2$ is tilted at angle $\alpha$. The reflected beams travel distances $z_1$ and $z_2$ respectively. Both beams recombine and are focused by lens $L$, forming an interference pattern at a screen at distance $D_a$; the pattern is observed in the $(x,y)$ plane at position $z$ and thickness $\Delta z$. The right inset shows the interference fringes along the $x$-axis in the $y$-$x$ plane. Arrows indicate the directions of light propagation.

question: Determine the radius $R_{m}$ of the interference ring with the interference order $m=48$ and wavelength $\lambda=600 \mathrm{~nm}$ in the interference pattern observed in the Fabry-P\xe9rot interferometer if the focal length of the focusing lens is $f=100 \mathrm{~mm}$ and the thickness of the air gap between the mirrors of the interferometer is $h=16 \mu \mathrm{~m}$.
subject: OPT
caption:

A parallel beam of rays enters from the left, passing through a "Scatterer" and an aperture of width $h$, then through a lens of aperture size $L$; the transmitted rays converge toward a focal plane at distance $f$, intersecting at point $R_m$ with all ray directions indicated by arrows toward the right.

question: Determine the diffraction divergence angle $\alpha$ of a light beam with wavelength $\lambda_{0}=600 \mathrm{~nm}$ passed through a circular aperture with diameter $D=0.06 \mathrm{~mm}$ in an opaque screen.
subject: OPT
caption:

Two parallel beams encounter a slit of width $D$; after passing through the slit, the beams diffract outward at symmetric angles $\alpha$ above and below the original direction, with arrows indicating the directions of propagation and the angles labeled as $\alpha$.

question: An opaque screen with a circular aperture of diameter $D=$ 15 mm is placed in a converging laser beam with wavelength $\\lambda_{0}=0.6328 \\mu \\mathrm{~m}$. subject: OPT

question: A perfectly aberration-corrected (diffraction-limited) optical system with exit pupil diameter $D=10 \, \mathrm{mm}$ is used to focus a parallel laser beam. A convex lens of diameter $D$ focuses incident parallel rays onto a point on its axis at the focal point $F$; the focal length $f$ is indicated as the distance from the lens to $F$, while parallel incident rays and their converging paths after refraction through the lens are shown by arrows.

question: A collimated laser beam with wavelength $\\lambda_{0}=0.63 \\mu \\mathrm{~m}$ is transformed by an optical system consisting of two aberration-free objectives $\\mathrm{L}_{1}$ and $\\mathrm{L}_{2}$. Determine the diameter $d$ of the laser beam focused by objective $\\mathrm{L}_{2}$ if the diameter of its exit pupil is $D_{2}=10 \\mathrm{~mm}$ and the focus length is $f_{2}=50 \\mathrm{~mm}$. The distance between the back focus of objective $\\mathrm{L}_{1}$ and objective $\\mathrm{L}_{2}$ is $z_{2}=150 \\mathrm{~mm}$. question: Determine the number $m$ of Fresnel zones that fit into the circular aperture in an opaque screen for point P (see the figure), in which a minimum of intensity $I(z)$ is observed in the diffraction pattern on optical axis $z$.
subject: OPT

question: Determine the resolution of the microscope $\\Delta x$ for object A in green light $\\left(\\lambda_{0}=0.55 \\mu \\mathrm{~m}\\right)$, given that the numerical aperture $NA = n \\sin \\alpha = 0.2$.
subject: OPT

question: A collimated beam of light with wavelength $\lambda_{0}=596 \mathrm{~nm}$ is normally incident on a diffraction grating DG with the period of grooves $d=3 \mu \mathrm{~m}$. subject: OPT

Parallel light rays enter from the left, pass through a diffraction grating labeled "DG," and then through a lens labeled "L" with focal length $f$ on both sides, forming separated focal points at a screen where the vertical separation is denoted by $\Delta x$; arrows indicate the direction of light propagation through the system.

question: A collimated laser beam with wavelength $\lambda_{0}=0.65 \mu \mathrm{~m}$ is incident at angle $\alpha_{0}=15 \mathrm{deg}$ on the diffraction grating DG with the period of grooves $d=2 \mu \mathrm{~m}$. Determine the angles $\beta_{+1}$ and $\beta_{-1}$ formed by the diffracted beams of light, corresponding to the diffraction orders +1 and -1, and the normal to the grating.
subject: OPT
caption:

A beam incident at angle $\alpha_0$ strikes a diffraction grating labeled "DG"; three outgoing rays are shown for diffraction orders $m = -1$, $m = 0$, and $m = 1$, emerging at angles labeled $\beta_{-1}$, $0$, and $\beta_{+1}$, respectively, with all directions indicated by arrowheads.

question: A crystal lattice may be considered as periodically arranged atom layers. If a collimated beam of $x$-ray radiation is incident on the crystal at a certain angle $\theta$ to the atom layers, one can observe the interference enhancement of waves reflected from the adjacent layers at the same angle $\theta$. Derive the equation-involving the angle $\theta$, the wavelength $\lambda_{0}$ of the x-ray radiation, and the period $\Lambda$ of atom layers-that determines the condition of phase matching and interference enhancement of the waves reflected from the atom layers.
subject: AMONP
caption:
IMAGE 1:
A crystal lattice with parallel atomic planes spaced by distance $\Lambda$ is shown, with dashed lines marking the planes and atoms as circles. Two incident rays and two reflected rays are depicted as bold arrows, each forming an angle $\theta$ with the planes, and interacting with the atoms at lattice points.

question: A pattern of interference of two laser plane waves with wavelength $\lambda_{1}=0.633 \mu \mathrm{~m}$ meeting at angle $2 \theta_{1}=45 \mathrm{deg}$ is recorded using a photographic plate with a photosensitive layer of thickness $h=10 \mu \mathrm{~m}$ and refractive index $n=1.4$. The photographic plate is perpendicular to the bisector of angle $2 \theta_{1}$. After light exposure, the plate is subjected to such photochemical procedures (development, fixing, and bleaching) that in the regions of maximal light intensity (light interference fringes), the refractive index of the photosensitive layer is increased. Thus, a volume phase diffraction grating is obtained with sinusoidal variation of the refractive index in the layer, characterized by the period $\Lambda \ll h$. At what angle $\theta_{2}$ should a laser beam with wavelength $\lambda_{2}=0.532 \mu \mathrm{~m}$ be directed at such a volume diffraction grating to observe the laser beam diffracted by the grating?
subject: OPT
caption:
IMAGE 1:
Two diagrams illustrating diffraction:

**Left:** A beam of wavelength $\lambda_1$ incident at various angles interacts with a thick, slab-shaped sample of thickness $h$. The beam is diffracted, producing reflected and transmitted beams; the diffraction angle is labeled $2\theta_1$.
  
**Right:** A beam of wavelength $\lambda_2$ is incident on a periodic structure of spacing $\Lambda$ and diffracted at angle $\theta_2$; the slit separation $\Lambda$ and outgoing/reflected ray directions are indicated.

question: Fresnel zones are constructed on the surface of the concave wavefront of a spherical wave surface that has radius $a$ and that converges into point S. question: A fiber optic gyroscope (fiber optic Sagnac interferometer) is mounted on a rotating platform. question: The light source S moves with velocity $\vec{v}_{s}$ in a direction forming angle $\alpha_{s}$ with the direction pointing at photodetector PD, which moves at angle $\alpha_{p}$ with respect to the same direction and has velocity $\vec{v}_{p}$. question: A laser beam with wavelength $\lambda_{0}=0.633 \mu \mathrm{~m}$ is diffracted by a phase diffraction grating DG moving with velocity $\vec{v}$ in its own plane perpendicularly to its grooves. question: In an interferometer with a diffraction grating DG used as an amplitude beam splitter, the first- and zero-order diffraction order beams are superposed using mirrors $\mathrm{M}_{1}$ and $\mathrm{M}_{2}$ and beam splitter (half-mirror) BS. question: In an interferometer with a diffraction grating DG used as an amplitude beam splitter, the first- and zero-order diffraction order beams are superposed using mirrors $\\mathrm{M}_{1}$ and $\\mathrm{M}_{2}$ and beam splitter (half-mirror) BS. question:
三端电阻，电容网络的 $Y-\Delta$ 变换。
三端电阻网络。
图1中左侧的三端电阻网络元，称为 $\Delta$ 型电阻网络元，右侧的三端电阻网络元，称为 Y 型电阻网络元。如果 Y 网络元中的 $a, b, c$ 端电势分别与 $\Delta$ 网络元中的 $A, B, C$ 端电势相同时，从 $a, b, c$ 端流入的电流分别与从 $A, B, C$ 端流入的电流相同，那么在任何一个大网络中此 Y 网络元与 $\Delta$ 网络元可以互相等效置换。
可以置换的前提是对 $\Delta$ 网络元中的每一组电阻 $R_{A B}, R_{B C}, R_{C A}$ ，必可为 Y 网络元找到一组对应的电阻 $R_{a}, R_{b}, R_{c}$ ，使得可置换的条件能够满足，或者反过来，对每一组 $R_{a}$ ， $R_{b}, R_{c}$ ，必可找到一组对应的 $R_{A B}, R_{B C}, R_{C A}$ ，使得可置换的条件能够满足。
参考图 2，因 Y 网络元中 $a, b, c$ 三点电势分别与 $\Delta$ 网络元中 $A, B, C$ 三点电势相同，两者间有如下电压关系：

$U_{a b}=U_{A B}, U_{b c}=U_{B C}, U_{c a}=U_{C A} .$

现在来考虑，为使 $Y$ 网络元中的电流与 $\Delta$ 网络元中的电流有如下对应关系

$I_{a}=I_{A}, \quad I_{b}=I_{B}, \quad I_{c}=I_{C},$

电阻 $\left(R_{a}, R_{b}, R_{c}\right)$ 与电阻 $\left(R_{A B}, R_{B C}, R_{C A}\right)$ 之间必须存在什么样的关系，
先分析 $I_{a}=I_{A}$ 的成立条件。
在 Y 网络元中有

$I_{a} R_{a}-I_{b} R_{b}=U_{a b}, I_{c} R_{c}-I_{a} R_{a}=U_{c a}, I_{a}+I_{b}+I_{c}=0,$

由此可解得

$I_{a}=\frac{R_{c}}{R_{a} R_{b}+R_{b} R_{c}+R_{c} R_{a}} U_{a b}-\frac{R_{b}}{R_{a} R_{b}+R_{b} R_{c}+R_{c} R_{a}} U_{c a} .$

在 $\Delta$ 网络元中则有

$I_{A B}=\frac{U_{A B}}{R_{A B}}, \quad I_{C A}=\frac{U_{C A}}{R_{C A}}, \quad I_{A}=I_{A B}-I_{C A},$

即得

$I_{A}=\frac{U_{A B}}{R_{A B}}-\frac{U_{C A}}{R_{C A}} .$

由 $I_{a}=I_{A}$ ，得

$\frac{R_{c}}{R_{a} R_{b}+R_{b} R_{c}+R_{c} R_{a}} U_{a b}-\frac{R_{b}}{R_{a} R_{b}+R_{b} R_{c}+R_{c} R_{a}} U_{c a}=\frac{U_{A B}}{R_{A B}}-\frac{U_{C A}}{R_{C A}} .$

因 $U_{a b}=U_{A B}, U_{c a}=U_{C A}$ ，便要求上式中对应的系数相等，即

$R_{A B} =\frac{\left(R_{a} R_{b}+R_{b} R_{c}+R_{c} R_{a}\right)}{R_{c}}, \quad R_{C A} =\frac{\left(R_{a} R_{b}+R_{b} R_{c}+R_{c} R_{a}\right)}{R_{b}}$

分析 $I_{b}=I_{B}, I_{c}=I_{C}$ 的成立条件，同样可得到与(1),(2)两式相似的四个关系式，其中两个与上述两式完全相同，另外两个同为

$R_{B C}=\frac{\left(R_{a} R_{b}+R_{b} R_{c}+R_{c} R_{a}\right)}{R_{a}} .$
(1),(2),(3)式即为满足可置换条件的第一组变换式。
(2),(3)式相除，可得

$R_{b}=\frac{R_{B C}}{R_{C A}} R_{a},$

(1),(3)式相除，可得

$R_{c}=\frac{R_{B C}}{R_{A B}} R_{a},$

将上述两式代入到(1)式的下述变形式

$R_{a}+R_{b}+\frac{R_{b}}{R_{c}} R_{a}=R_{A B},$

即可得

$R_{a}=\frac{R_{A B} R_{C A}}{\left(R_{A B}+R_{B C}+R_{C A}\right)},$

将此式代入到上面的 $R_{b} \sim R_{a}$ 和 $R_{c} \sim R_{a}$ 关系式，即得

$R_{b} =\frac{R_{A B} R_{B C}}{\left(R_{A B}+R_{B C}+R_{C A}\right)}, \quad R_{c} =\frac{R_{B C} R_{C A}}{\left(R_{A B}+R_{B C}+R_{C A}\right)} .$

事实上由于网络的对称性，可以通过对称地位置换(4)式中各电阻的下标字符直接导出(5), (6)两式，网络的对称性在(1),(2),(3)式中也明显地表现出来。(4),(5),(6)式即为满足可置换条件的第二组变换式。
三端电容网络。
由

$R=\frac{U}{I}, C=\frac{Q}{U} \xrightarrow{\text { 引入 }} C^{*}=\frac{1}{C}=\frac{U}{Q},$

因 $Q$ 与 $I$ 相当（例如串联相同，并联相加等），$U$ 与 $U$ 同量，可见 $C^{*}$ 与 $R$ 在数学关系上同构。引入新的 $C^{*}$ 参数后，直流电源，电容网络基本问题（即各电容器电量分布问题）的求解，完全类同于直流电源，电阻网络基本问题（即各电阻器电流分布问题）的求解。

图 3 中左侧的三端电容网络元，称为 $\Delta$ 型电容网络元，右侧的三端电容网络元，称为 Y 型电容网络元。其间也有等效变换，仿照电阻网络中 $\mathrm{Y}-\Delta$ 变换，必定可得

$\begin{array}{c}
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
C_{A B}^{*}=\left(C_{a}^{*} C_{b}^{*}+C_{b}^{*} C_{c}^{*}+C_{c}^{*} C_{a}^{*}\right) / C_{c}^{*}, 
C_{B C}^{*}=\left(C_{a}^{*} C_{b}^{*}+C_{b}^{*} C_{c}^{*}+C_{c}^{*} C_{a}^{*}\right) / C_{a}^{*}, 
C_{C A}^{*}=\left(C_{a}^{*} C_{b}^{*}+C_{b}^{*} C_{c}^{*}+C_{c}^{*} C_{a}^{*}\right) / C_{b}^{*},
\end{array}\right. 
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
C_{a}^{*}=C_{A B}^{*} C_{C A}^{*} /\left(C_{A B}^{*}+C_{B C}^{*}+C_{C A}^{*}\right), 
C_{b}^{*}=C_{A B}^{*} C_{B C}^{*} /\left(C_{A B}^{*}+C_{B C}^{*}+C_{C A}^{*}\right), 
C_{C}^{*}=C_{B C}^{*} C_{C A}^{*} /\left(C_{A B}^{*}+C_{B C}^{*}+C_{C A}^{*}\right) .
\end{array}\right.
\end{array}$

再替换成电容量 $C=C^{*-1}$ ，便有

$\begin{array}{c}
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
C_{A B}=C_{a} C_{b} /\left(C_{a}+C_{b}+C_{c}\right), 
C_{B C}=C_{b} C_{c} /\left(C_{a}+C_{b}+C_{c}\right), 
C_{C A}=C_{c} C_{a} /\left(C_{a}+C_{b}+C_{c}\right),
\end{array}\right. 
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
C_{a}=\left(C_{A B} C_{B C}+C_{B C} C_{C A}+C_{C A} C_{A B}\right) / C_{B C} . 
C_{b}=\left(C_{A B} C_{B C}+C_{B C} C_{C A}+C_{C A} C_{A B}\right) / C_{C A} . 
C_{c}=\left(C_{A B} C_{B C}+C_{B C} C_{C A}+C_{C A} C_{A B}\right) / C_{A B} .
\end{array}\right.
\end{array}$

数学上，(7),(8),(9)式相当(4),(5),(6)式，(10),(11),(12)式相当(1),(2), (3)式。可见，电容的 $Y-\Delta$ 变换正好与电阻的 $Y-\Delta$ 变换成颠倒关系。下面求解：
由电阻丝构成的等边三角形电阻网络如图 4 所示，已知每一小段电阻丝的电阻为 $r_{0}$ ，试求 $B, C$ 间的等效电阻 $R_{B C}$ 。
subject: EM

question:
三端电阻，电容网络的 $Y-\Delta$ 变换．
（i）三端电阻网络．
图1中左侧的三端电阻网络元，称为 $\Delta$ 型电阻网络元，右侧的三端电阻网络元，称为 Y 型电阻网络元．如果 Y 网络元中的 $a, b, c$ 端电势分别与 $\Delta$ 网络元中的 $A, B, C$ 端电势相同时，从 $a, b, c$ 端流人的电流分别与从 $A, B, C$ 端流人的电流相同，那么在任一个大网络中此 Y 网络元与 $\Delta$ 网络元可以互相等效置换．

可以置换的前提是对 $\Delta$ 网络元中的每一组电阻 $R_{A B}, R_{B C}, R_{C A}$ ，必可为 Y 网络元找到一组对应的电阻 $R_{a}, R_{b}, R_{c}$ ，使得可置换的条件能够满足．或者反过来，对每一组 $R_{a}$ ， $R_{b}, R_{c}$ ，必可找到一组对应的 $R_{A B}, R_{B C}, R_{C A}$ ，使得可置换的条件能够满足．

参考图 2，因 Y 网络元中 $a, b, c$ 三点电势分别与 $\Delta$ 网络元中 $A, B, C$ 三点电势相同，两者间有如下电压关系：
$$
U_{a b}=U_{A B}, U_{b c}=U_{B C}, U_{c a}=U_{C A} .
$$
现在来考虑，为使 $Y$ 网络元中的电流与 $\Delta$ 网络元中的电流有如下对应关系
$$
I_{a}=I_{A}, \quad I_{b}=I_{B}, \quad I_{c}=I_{C},
$$

电阻 $\left(R_{a}, R_{b}, R_{c}\right)$ 与电阻 $\left(R_{A B}, R_{B C}, R_{C A}\right)$ 之间必须存在什么样的关系．
先分析 $I_{a}=I_{A}$ 的成立条件。
在 Y 网络元中有
$$
I_{a} R_{a}-I_{b} R_{b}=U_{a b}, I_{c} R_{c}-I_{a} R_{a}=U_{c a}, I_{a}+I_{b}+I_{c}=0,
$$

由此可解得
$$
I_{a}=\frac{R_{c}}{R_{a} R_{b}+R_{b} R_{c}+R_{c} R_{a}} U_{a b}-\frac{R_{b}}{R_{a} R_{b}+R_{b} R_{c}+R_{c} R_{a}} U_{c a} .
$$

在 $\Delta$ 网络元中则有
$$
I_{A B}=\frac{U_{A B}}{R_{A B}}, \quad I_{C A}=\frac{U_{C A}}{R_{C A}}, \quad I_{A}=I_{A B}-I_{C A},
$$

即得
$$
I_{A}=\frac{U_{A B}}{R_{A B}}-\frac{U_{C A}}{R_{C A}} .
$$

由 $I_{a}=I_{A}$ ，得
$$
\frac{R_{c}}{R_{a} R_{b}+R_{b} R_{c}+R_{c} R_{a}} U_{a b}-\frac{R_{b}}{R_{a} R_{b}+R_{b} R_{c}+R_{c} R_{a}} U_{c a}=\frac{U_{A B}}{R_{A B}}-\frac{U_{C A}}{R_{C A}} .
$$

因 $U_{a b}=U_{A B}, U_{c a}=U_{C A}$ ，便要求上式中对应的系数相等，即
$$
\begin{aligned}
R_{A B} & =\frac{\left(R_{a} R_{b}+R_{b} R_{c}+R_{c} R_{a}\right)}{R_{c}}, 
R_{C A} & =\frac{\left(R_{a} R_{b}+R_{b} R_{c}+R_{c} R_{a}\right)}{R_{b}}
\end{aligned}
$$

分析 $I_{b}=I_{B}, I_{c}=I_{C}$ 的成立条件，同样可得到与（1），（2）两式相似的四个关系式，其中两个与上述两式完全相同，另外两个同为
$$
R_{B C}=\frac{\left(R_{a} R_{b}+R_{b} R_{c}+R_{c} R_{a}\right)}{R_{a}} .
$$
（1），（2），（3）式即为满足可置换条件的第一组变换式．
（2），（3）式相除，可得
$$
R_{b}=\frac{R_{B C}}{R_{C A}} R_{a},
$$
（1），（3）式相除，可得
$$
R_{c}=\frac{R_{B C}}{R_{A B}} R_{a},
$$

将上述两式代人到（1）式的下述变形式
$$
R_{a}+R_{b}+\frac{R_{b}}{R_{c}} R_{a}=R_{A B},
$$

即可得
$$
R_{a}=\frac{R_{A B} R_{C A}}{\left(R_{A B}+R_{B C}+R_{C A}\right)},
$$

将此式代人到上面的 $R_{b} \sim R_{a}$ 和 $R_{c} \sim R_{a}$ 关系式，即得
$$
\begin{aligned}
R_{b} & =\frac{R_{A B} R_{B C}}{\left(R_{A B}+R_{B C}+R_{C A}\right)}, 
R_{c} & =\frac{R_{B C} R_{C A}}{\left(R_{A B}+R_{B C}+R_{C A}\right)} .
\end{aligned}
$$

事实上由于网络的对称性，可以通过对称地置换（4）式中各电阻的下标字符直接导出（5）， （6）两式，网络的对称性在（1），（2），（3）式中也明显地表现出来．（4），（5），（6）式即为满足可置换条件的第二组变换式．
（ii）三端电容网络。
由
$$
R=\frac{U}{I}, C=\frac{Q}{U} \xrightarrow{\text { 引人 }} C^{*}=\frac{1}{C}=\frac{U}{Q},
$$

因 $Q$ 与 $I$ 相当（例如串联相同，并联相加等），$U$ 与 $U$ 同量，可见 $C^{*}$ 与 $R$ 在数学关系上同构。引人新的 $C^{*}$ 参量后，直流电源，电容网络基本问题（即各电容器电量分布问题）的求解，完全类同于直流电源，电阻网络基本问题（即各电阻器电流分布问题）的求解．

图 3 中左侧的三端电容网络元，称为 $\Delta$ 型电容网络元，右侧的三端电容网络元，称为 Y 型电容网络元．其间也有等效变换，仿照电阻网络中 $\mathrm{Y}-\Delta$ 变换，必定可得
$$
\begin{array}{c}
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
C_{A B}^{*}=\left(C_{a}^{*} C_{b}^{*}+C_{b}^{*} C_{c}^{*}+C_{c}^{*} C_{a}^{*}\right) / C_{c}^{*}, 
C_{B C}^{*}=\left(C_{a}^{*} C_{b}^{*}+C_{b}^{*} C_{c}^{*}+C_{c}^{*} C_{a}^{*}\right) / C_{a}^{*}, 
C_{C A}^{*}=\left(C_{a}^{*} C_{b}^{*}+C_{b}^{*} C_{c}^{*}+C_{c}^{*} C_{a}^{*}\right) / C_{b}^{*},
\end{array}\right. 
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
C_{a}^{*}=C_{A B}^{*} C_{C A}^{*} /\left(C_{A B}^{*}+C_{B C}^{*}+C_{C A}^{*}\right), 
C_{b}^{*}=C_{A B}^{*} C_{B C}^{*} /\left(C_{A B}^{*}+C_{B C}^{*}+C_{C A}^{*}\right), 
C_{C}^{*}=C_{B C}^{*} C_{C A}^{*} /\left(C_{A B}^{*}+C_{B C}^{*}+C_{C A}^{*}\right) .
\end{array}\right.
\end{array}
$$

再替换成电容量 $C=C^{*-1}$ ，便有
$$
\begin{array}{c}
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
C_{A B}=C_{a} C_{b} /\left(C_{a}+C_{b}+C_{c}\right), 
C_{B C}=C_{b} C_{c} /\left(C_{a}+C_{b}+C_{c}\right), 
C_{C A}=C_{c} C_{a} /\left(C_{a}+C_{b}+C_{c}\right),
\end{array}\right. 
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
C_{a}=\left(C_{A B} C_{B C}+C_{B C} C_{C A}+C_{C A} C_{A B}\right) / C_{B C} . 
C_{b}=\left(C_{A B} C_{B C}+C_{B C} C_{C A}+C_{C A} C_{A B}\right) / C_{C A} . 
C_{c}=\left(C_{A B} C_{B C}+C_{B C} C_{C A}+C_{C A} C_{A B}\right) / C_{A B} .
\end{array}\right.
\end{array}
$$

数学上，（7），（8），（9）式相当（4），（5），（6）式，（10），（11），（12）式相当（1），（2）， （3）式．可见，电容的 $Y-\Delta$ 变换正好与电阻的 $Y-\Delta$ 变换成颠倒关系．由小电容器构成的等边三角形电容网络如图 5 所示，已知每一个小电容器的电容为 $C_{0}$ ，试求 $B, C$ 间的等效电容 $C_{B C}$ 。
